candidates.title: Did a Pink Volcano Erupt in New Zealand?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A video shows a pink volcano erupting in New Zealand.
Rating:
False
About this rating
A video purportedly showing bright fuschia smoke billowing from a volcano frequently appears on social media, along with a claim that it shows an actual "pink volcano" erupting in New Zealand:
Pink eruption of the volcano in New Zealand
The video does not explain what chemical process might turn smoke or steam this particular shade (although with the proper dyes, it is possible to turn smoke into a veritable rainbow), but it isn't particularly relevant anyway; this video does not depict an actual volcanic eruption.
The "pink volcano" video was created by artist Filip Hodas, and was originally shared to his Facebook page in December 2016. Hodas posted the video to Instagram (with tags such as #3D, #photoshop, #render, and #animation), and provided extra insight into how the video was created in response to a query on Facebook:
pretty much! depends on what I need. In this case I layered few planes with wm maps on top of each other and added a lot of zdepth fog to blend it in.
No records of volcanos emitting bright pink smoke exist, except those created by digital artists.
candidates.description: Video purportedly showing oddly-colored smoke and steam rising from a eruption was digitally manipulated.

result.explanation: The news caption is False. Snopes.com fact-check explicitly states that the video depicting a pink volcano erupting in New Zealand is digitally manipulated and not an actual event.  The fact-check details how the video was created by an artist and provides evidence that no such volcanic event occurred.

final_result.explanation: The news caption claiming a video shows a pink volcano erupting in New Zealand is definitively false based on both internal and external validation.  The internal analysis reveals a significant discrepancy between the caption and the image. The image shows a vibrant pink and purple cloud of smoke, lacking any geological features associated with a volcanic eruption. There is no visible landscape, geological formations, or context that would support a claim of a volcanic eruption in New Zealand.  The lack of visual evidence of a volcanic event completely contradicts the caption's claim.  This internal inconsistency raises serious doubts about the accuracy of the original caption. The external validation strongly supports this conclusion. A fact-check by Snopes.com confirms that the video in question is a digitally manipulated creation, not a genuine recording of a volcanic eruption in New Zealand.  The fact-check definitively states that the video is the work of an artist, Filip Hodas, and that no such event took place. They provide detailed information on the video's origin, its creation, and the deliberate nature of its artistic manipulation.  The fact-check's high confidence score (10) and its detailed explanation leave no room for doubt about the video's authenticity. The external validation fully corroborates the internal analysis, indicating a complete mismatch between the image content and the caption's claims.  Both assessments independently and conclusively demonstrate that the caption is out of context; there's no evidence to link the artistic creation in the video to a volcanic event in New Zealand. The high agreement between the internal (confidence score: 0) and external (confidence score: 10) assessments leads to a strong conclusion that the caption is completely false and out of context. There is no ambiguity or uncertainty regarding this conclusion.  No reasonable interpretation of the visual evidence, coupled with the definitive external confirmation, would suggest otherwise. The visual discrepancy, lack of supporting evidence, and the explicit external debunking converge to a highly confident assessment of the caption's falsity.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation conclusively demonstrate that the news caption is false.  Internal analysis reveals a complete mismatch between the image (pink and purple smoke cloud) and the caption's description (a pink volcano erupting in New Zealand). External fact-checking by Snopes.com definitively confirms that the video is digitally manipulated, not a real event, further corroborating the internal findings.
